Award.AwardTitle: IBSS: New Methods for Investigating the Formation of Individual and Shared Concepts and Their Dynamic Dispersion Across Related Societies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research project will develop and test new mathematical models that explore the ways through which conceptual meaning is represented in languages as those languages change in complexity over time. The project investigators also will examine the ways such meaning is shared among groups of individuals in societies. The project's models will describe the dynamic development of concepts as a geometric system and will provide methods for understanding the linguistic representation of concepts and the ways semantic meaning from one community can be influenced by that of neighboring communities. Although this project will focus on the ways that color terms have evolved within languages and societies, the insights and information from this project will apply beyond the domain of color representation to any set of concepts in which objects have a similarity structure that can be assessed and described mathematically. Examples of the kinds of situations where the approach and methods to be developed during this project will have utility are the following: (1) the development of unambiguous and formally scalable artificial intelligence and robotic analogs of human classification and categorization systems; (2) the development of a global communication methodology that could be used to enhance rapid global information messaging capabilities; and (3) the construction of standardized systems for information representation in critical systems, such as medical diagnostic systems and transportation systems.

The formation and communication of concepts permeate a diverse range of human activities. They play roles in education systems; in the organization and design of transportation systems; in the physical and virtual design of retail markets and consumer goods; in classifications of quality and risk in medical diagnoses; in business performance; and in social values. Psychologists, linguists, anthropologists, computer scientists, and other scholars have studied concepts by focusing on specific examples of concept formation while trying to understand how such conceptual systems are formed. One specific concept that has received attention is how color terms "evolve" and how their conceptual meaning is understood and shared by members of a society. Conceptualization of color is an important special case because color stimuli can be precisely measured and easily duplicated, and the human perceptual space of a million colors can be described with mathematical precision. This project will focus on the development and testing of mathematical models that capture the ways color term concepts are categorized and shared. The models to be designed and tested will use geometric formalisms for characterizing meaning in general and will specifically demonstrate their use by investigating color terms and concepts. Testing will use data from a wide variety of societies, including the Mesoamerican Color Survey (MCS), a database of systematically collected categorization behaviors of 900 individuals who have communicated with one or more of 116 endangered or developing languages that are at various stages of color lexicon development. The MCS is largely in hand-written form, and one product of this project will be its full digitalization using modern computer science crowd-sourcing methods. Full digitalization of the MCS database will make it available for use by the global scientific community for the first time. This project is supported through the NSF Interdisciplinary Behavioral and Social Sciences Research (IBSS) competition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From this project new knowledge has been produced and we have (a) advances basic scientific understanding of concept formation and representation of natural categories; (b) provided the legacy of a new and extensive public database for academic researchers seeking to examine the linguistic and cognitive processing impacts across a wide range of cultures; (c) provided novel scientific theory and methods generalized from areas outside the principal discipline, and (d) provided an infrastructure for, and actual experience in, scientific and educational training (STEM opportunities) for students possessing linguistic or cultural competence in languages investigated. Thus, the project, in addition to basic research results in the area, makes available to the public for the first time one of the most extensive public archives on color categorization data across ethnolinguistic groups. This online resource is potentially poised to serve as a dynamic repository of novel color categorization and a collaborative research platform for color categorization investigations.

During the reported funding period (09/01/2018 to 02/28/2019) work focused on 5 specific aims: (1) Continued development of methods to transcribing and digitalize archival color survey data, and to update the published project URL containing the first stages of its digitalization, and futher updating the published site known as the ColCat Wiki and making it publicly available as a resource to the scientific community (http://colcat.calit2.uci.edu/). (2) Produce new mathematical models describing the geometric relationships between "Basic" color categories, color category boundaries, category Best-Exemplars, and modeling and simulating individual variations in color similarity space. (3) Conduct in silico investigations of evolution, spatial diffusion and mutation in WCS and MCS societies. (4) Finalize project work in-progress and publishing peer-reviewed articles in top-tier research journals.  (5) Organize and conduct an international conference on the topic of the funded research as an opportunity for collaborative exchange among experts in the area and dissemination of results of the award period (see conference video deck https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLQw7KTnzkpXeQie7E-pl9iSw39Lqycbld).

The present NSF research project is the first of its kind to (a) rescue from destruction, (b) organize and publically disseminate, and (c) investigate in silico a largely unexplored archive (the MacLaury Database Color Naming and Categorization Archive) that includes from 116 unindustrialized societies of Mesoamerican indigenous peoples, plus 92 various language groups sampled worldwide from both rural and industrialized societies. The surveys of native-language monolingual speakers are evaluated using standardized color categorization procedures, and can never be replaced since 116 of those languages include some that are now extinct, with most being currently endangered.

The present work has employed subsets of these data, and data from the existing World Color Survey Database, as the topic of investigation using a set of sophisticated analysis procedures and methods, to rigorously model how categorization and concepts are represented when language differences exist. This has greatly contributed important advances to concept formation and knowledge sharing, and to the specific understanding of color categorization and naming for the particular languages in the database. It also has major potential for contributing to a globally-engaged STEM workforce by its focus of applying rigorous scientific analyses to a multinational ethnically-diverse groups of native language speakers for understanding group-specific features as well as universal features of semantic representation.

Intellectual Merit: The funded project has advanced knowledge on (i) human cognitive processing of concepts in individuals, (ii) the sharing of semantic meaning within ethnolinguistic groups of individuals, and (iii) the communication of concepts and meaning across groups of different ethnolinguistic backgrounds. These were explored using color semantics (advancing knowledge in that area directly), with the results that are generally extendable, or, at a minimum, highly informative, to semantic meaning across fields of cognitive concept formation and belief systems.

Broader Impacts: The funded project has benefitted a global research community through it's involvement developing tools, procedures and resources for inclusion in an internet-based collaborative research space being developed as a public-access archive website and Wiki. The final year of the project has extended the international collaboration and extended access to developers interested in analyzing the public-access archive. It is anticipated that the impacts of the project continue to develop following novel research that is underway and following a forthcoming invited feature contribution on the topic of the grant to a top specialty journal (Optics & Photonics News (OPN) -- The American Optical Society). We fully expect the products of the research, in particular, the archive platform, will ultimately achieve further transformative training potential that as a public-domain research tool for users interested in learning about and researching cross-cultural categorization behaviors via an internet-based platform. An explicit goal of the project has been to extend its impact through integration of developed procedures and resources into the realm of research education, which ongoing work has initiated and which will be an exceptional contribution.
